title: Pontic Greek
text:
Pontic Greek (Pontic Greek: , or ; , ) is a <a href="Varieties%20of%20Modern%20Greek">variety of Modern Greek</a> originally spoken in the <a href="Pontus%20%28region%29">Pontus</a> area on the southern shores of the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>, northeastern <a href="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, the Eastern Turkish/<a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> province of <a href="Kars">Kars</a>, southern <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a> and today mainly in northern <a href="Greece">Greece</a>. Its speakers are referred to as <a href="Pontic%20Greeks">Pontic Greeks</a> or Pontian Greeks.
The linguistic lineage of Pontic Greek stems from <a href="Ionic%20Greek">Ionic Greek</a> via <a href="Koine%20Greek">Koine</a> and <a href="Byzantine%20Greek">Byzantine Greek</a>, and contains influences from <a href="Georgian%20language">Georgian</a>, <a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a>, <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a>, <a href="Armenian%20language">Armenian</a>, and <a href="Kurdish%20language">Kurdish</a>.
Pontic Greek is an endangered <a href="Indo-European%20languages">Indo-European language</a> spoken by about 778,000 people worldwide. Many Pontians live in Greece; however, only 200,000–300,000 of those are considered active Pontic speakers. Although it is mainly spoken in Northern Greece, it is also spoken in Turkey, Russia, <a href="Armenia">Armenia</a>, Georgia and Kazakhstan and by the Pontic diaspora. The language was brought to Greece in the 1920s after the population exchange between the Christian Pontic Greeks and the Turkish Muslims from their homelands during the <a href="Population%20exchange%20between%20Greece%20and%20Turkey">1923 population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>. However, it is still spoken in pockets of the <a href="Pontus%20%28region%29">Pontus</a> today, mostly by <a href="Greek%20Muslims%23Greek%20Muslims%20of%20Pontus%20and%20the%20Caucasus">Pontic Greek Muslims</a> in the eastern districts of <a href="Trabzon%20Province">Trabzon Province</a>. Pontic Greek is considered a dialect of modern Greek; however, the two varieties are not mutually intelligible. It is primarily written in the <a href="Greek%20alphabet">Greek script</a>, while in Turkey and Ukraine the Latin script is used more frequently.
Classification.
Pontic Greek is classified as an <a href="Indo-European%20languages">Indo-European</a>, <a href="Greek%20language">Greek language</a> of the <a href="Attic%20Greek">Attic</a>-<a href="Ionic%20Greek">Ionic</a> branch.
Name.
Historically, the speakers of Pontic Greek called it simply "Romeyka" (or "Romeika", ), which is also a historical and colloquial term for Modern Greek in general. The term "Pontic" originated in scholarly usage, but it has been adopted as a mark of identity by Pontic Greeks living in Greece.
Similarly, in <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a>, there is no special name for Pontic Greek; it is called "Rumca" (), derived from the Turkish word "<a href="R%C3%BBm%23Ottoman%20usage">Rum</a>", denoting Byzantine Greeks.
Nowadays, Pontic speakers living in Turkey call their language "Romeyka, Rumca" or "Rumcika".
History.
Similar to most modern Greek dialects, Pontic Greek is mainly derived from Koine Greek, which was spoken in the <a href="Hellenistic%20period">Hellenistic</a> and <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Roman</a> times between the 4th century BC and the 4th century AD. Following the <a href="Seljuk%20Empire">Seljuk invasion of Asia Minor</a> during the 11th century AD, Pontus became isolated from many of the regions of the Byzantine Empire. The Pontians remained somewhat isolated from the mainland Greeks, causing Pontic Greek to develop separately and distinctly from the rest of the mainland Greek. However, the language has also been influenced by the nearby Persian, <a href="Languages%20of%20the%20Caucasus">Caucasian</a>, and Turkish languages.

Ophitic.
The inhabitants of the <a href="Of%2C%20Turkey">Of valley</a> who had converted to Islam in the 17th century <a href="Greek%20Muslims">remained in Turkey</a> and have partly retained the Pontic language until today. Their dialect, which forms part of the Trapezountiac subgroup, is called "Ophitic" by linguists, but speakers generally call it "Romeika". As few as 5,000 people are reported to speak it. There are however estimates that show the real number of the speakers as considerably higher. Speakers of Ophitic/Romeyka are concentrated in the eastern districts of Trabzon province: <a href="%C3%87aykara">Çaykara</a> (Katohor), <a href="Dernekpazar%C4%B1">Dernekpazarı</a> (Kondu), <a href="S%C3%BCrmene">Sürmene</a> (Sourmena) and <a href="K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCba%C5%9F%C4%B1%2C%20Trabzon">Köprübaşı</a> (Göneşera). Although less widespread, it is still spoken in some remote villages of the Of district itself. It is also spoken in the western <a href="%C4%B0kizdere">İkizdere</a> (Dipotamos) district of Rize province. Historically the dialect was spoken in a wider area, stretching further east to the port town of <a href="Pazar%2C%20Rize">Pazar</a> (Athina).
Ophitic has retained the <a href="infinitive">infinitive</a>, which is present in <a href="Ancient%20Greek">Ancient Greek</a> but has been lost in other variants of Modern Greek; it has therefore been characterized as "archaic" or <a href="Linguistic%20conservatism">conservative</a> (even in relation to other Pontic dialects) and as the living language that is closest to Ancient Greek. Because a majority of the population of these districts converted to Islam during the 17th to 19th centuries, some Arabic and Turkish loanwords have been adopted in the language. According to Vahit Tursun, writer of the Romeika-Turkish dictionary, loanwords from the neighboring Laz speakers of Rize province are strikingly absent in the Romeika vocabulary of Trabzon natives.
A very similar dialect is spoken by descendants of <a href="Christians">Christians</a> from the Of valley (especially from <a href="Dernekpazar%C4%B1">Kondu</a>) now living in Greece in the village of <a href="Nea%20Trapezounta%2C%20Pieria">Nea Trapezounta, Pieria</a>, <a href="Central%20Macedonia">Central Macedonia</a>, with about 400 speakers.
Geographic distribution.
Though Pontic was originally spoken on the southern shores of the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>, from the 18th and 19th century and on substantial numbers migrated into the northern and eastern shores, into the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>. Pontic is still spoken by large numbers of people in <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, mainly in <a href="Mariupol">Mariupol</a>, but also in other parts of Ukraine such as the <a href="Odessa">Odessa</a> and <a href="Donetsk">Donetsk</a> region, in <a href="Russia">Russia</a> (around <a href="Stavropol">Stavropol</a>) and <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>. The language enjoyed some use as a literary medium in the 1930s, including a school grammar (Topkharas 1998 [1932]).
After the <a href="Greek%20genocide">massacres of the 1910s</a>, the majority of speakers remaining in <a href="Asia%20Minor">Asia Minor</a> were subject to the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> <a href="Exchange%20of%20populations%20between%20Greece%20and%20Turkey">population exchange</a>, and were resettled in Greece (mainly northern Greece). A second wave of migration occurred in the early 1990s, this time from countries of the <a href="former%20Soviet%20Union">former Soviet Union</a>.
In Greece, Pontic is now many times used only emblematically rather than as a medium of communication due to the mixing of Pontic and other Greeks.
Official status.
Greece.
In Greece, Pontic has no official status, like all other Greek dialects.
Soviet Union.
Historically, Pontic Greek was the "de facto" language of the Greek minority in the <a href="USSR">USSR</a>, although in the Πανσυνδεσμιακή Σύσκεψη ("Pansyndesmiakí Sýskepsi", All-Union Conference) of 1926, organised by the Greek-Soviet <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a>, it was decided that <a href="Dimotiki">Demotic</a> should be the official language of the community.
Later revival of Greek identity in the Soviet Union and post-Communist Russia saw a renewed division on the issue of <a href="Mariupol%20Greek">Rumaiic</a> versus Demotic. A new attempt to preserve a sense of ethnic Rumaiic identity started in the mid-1980s. The Ukrainian scholar <a href="Andriy%20Biletsky%20%28linguist%29">Andriy Biletsky</a> created a new Slavonic alphabet, but though a number of writers and poets make use of this alphabet, the population of the region rarely uses it.
Culture.
The language has a rich oral tradition and folklore and Pontic songs are particularly popular in Greece. There is also some limited production of modern literature in Pontic, including <a href="poetry%20collections">poetry collections</a> (among the most renowned writers is <a href="Kostas%20Diamantidis">Kostas Diamantidis</a>), novels, and translated <a href="Asterix">Asterix</a> <a href="comic%20album">comic album</a>s. The youth often speak standard Greek as their first language. The use of Pontic has been maintained more by speakers in North America than it has in Greece.
Alphabets.
Pontic, in Greece, is written in the <a href="Greek%20alphabet">Greek alphabet</a>, with diacritics: for , for (phonological ). Pontic, in Turkey, is written in the <a href="Latin%20alphabet">Latin alphabet</a> following Turkish conventions. In Russia, it is written in the <a href="Cyrillic%20alphabet">Cyrillic alphabet</a>.
